body:
Thanks again for getting in touch and opening the issue here! 

A few comments: 
* We have an interface for updating forecasters: `update(y_new, X_new=None, ...)`, perhaps we can re-use that? 
* Could you add some references for the other ensemble algorithms? 
* What's the output of `online_predict()` and how would that be different from calling `update()` and `predict()` sequentially?

- For the interface for updating forecasters, yes we can totally re-use that
- For a Hedge based algorithm, I was hoping to implement https://cseweb.ucsd.edu/~yfreund/papers/nhedge.pdf and for NNLS scipy offers an implementation https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy-0.14.0/reference/generated/scipy.optimize.nnls.html. There are other best expert prediction algorithms that are better for non-stationary settings that I'm trying to read up on https://users.soe.ucsc.edu/~manfred/pubs/J39.pdf
-  The output of online prediction would be the prediction for some input X but the catch is that after each prediction, the update is performed. It would definitely be possible to do update() and predict() sequentially and the function itself is really just a faster way of implementing that so I think leaving it out would be good.
We also have an `update_predict_single` method if there are more efficient implementations for updating and predicting. There's also an `update_predict` function for model evaluation purposes.

Sorry, I couldn't find this method within the `BaseForecaster`, `BaseUpdateableForecaster`, or `EnsembleForecaster` classes. Could the functionality of `update_predict` be extended to the `EnsembleForecaster` class?
Would unit tests be required for each of the ensemble algorithms? I have some examples in the forms of notebooks to show qualitative behavior but nothing that can be run on a script for exact values?

Ah sorry, most of the forecasting functionality is still on the `dev` branch, we'll push it to master soon. Unit tests would be needed, but it's easy to write them up if you already have some examples.
I see, in the meantime, I can work on adding different algorithms and further tuning some examples?

Hi, I was trying to implement an online training method by rewriting the update_predict with a cv that will split my data into parts where I update the forecaster with the current step and predict the next step and I was wondering how I would implement such a cv. I was thinking that something like:

Input:
y_train = [1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9]

Output:
```python
for new_window, _ in cv.split(y_train):
   print(new_window)
   print(_)
```

Expected Partitions:
[1]
[2]
[1,2]
[3]
[1,2,3]
[4]
....

I'm mostly looking at the code for `_predict_moving_cutoff` from _sktime.py, I want to understand how `_update_predict_single`

But based on the update step, I wasn't sure how the update saves the new window. I was thinking maybe a cv with the output:

Expected Partitions:
[1]
[2]
[2]
[3]
[3]
[4]

Would work if the update step saved the previous step.

Hi @magittan, we've got a sliding window splitter: 

```python
from sktime.forecasting.model_selection import SlidingWindowSplitter
from sktime.datasets import load_airline

y = load_airline().iloc[:10]
cv = SlidingWindowSplitter(start_with_window=True, window_length=5, fh=[1, 2])
for train_window, test_window in cv.split(y):
    print(train_window, test_window)

> [0 1 2 3 4] [5 6]
> [1 2 3 4 5] [6 7]
> [2 3 4 5 6] [7 8]
> [3 4 5 6 7] [8 9]
```
Does that help?
I guess my question is more about how the forecaster's update function works. I see that it updates the `oh` parameter with the total amount of data seen so far, but does it also fit on that data?

That's controlled by the `update_params` kwargs. Many algorithms allow to updated fitted parameters incrementally from new data, without having to refit the whole model. Updating is often also more efficient than refitting. For example, an ARIMA model can be updated using Kalman smoothing. The idea is to implement these methods inside the update functionality. So, if you set `update_params=True`, fitted parameters and as well as the observation horizon (`oh`) would be updated, otherwise only the observation horizon would be updated. 

But I'm very open to and would appreciate new ideas, feedback on the current design. :)

I see, this model definitely makes sense. I guess I was just unsure of how (or if even) to allow the forecasters to refit when data comes in. I think I'll first consider the simpler case where no refit is needed for the forecaster and rather the ensemble will fit itself during a validation stretch of data.

issue.title: New Ensemble Forecasting Methods

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look at
the extension guidelines: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
Refers to #271 for implementing New Online Ensemble Forecasting Methods


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
This implements hedge based DTOL for choosing how to weight different forecasters in an online format, I included some implementations of these algorithms with more to come:
- NormalHedge
- Hedge (Incremental/Doubling)

I also included one that is very similar to stacking that performs a non-negative least squares fit from the forecasters to the output.

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one? 
Currently, the online experts algorithms are included as a script, but as more are added, it would be good to include more in a dedicated repository for online experts.

#### PR checklist for new estimators 
For the 'OnlineEnsembleForecaster' I have:

- [x] I have added unit tests and made sure they pass locally. 
- [x] I have updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my algorithm works.
- [x] I have updated sktime's [estimator overview](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/ESTIMATOR_OVERVIEW.md) and I'm committed to maintain my contribution and provide bug fixes if necessary.

#### Any other comments?
I also added a cv method called 'OnlineSplitter' which helps me control the behavior of update_predict for forecasting in an online fashion.
